Authors:
Pamela D. Roberts, Cheng-Hua Huang, Lawrence E.
Datnoff
Title:
Molecular phylogeny and divergence times of Fusarium
oxysporum f. sp. radicis-lycopersici inferred from multilocus DNA
sequences
Keywords:
Fusarium oxysporum, Fusarium crown and root rot, Fusarium
wilt, IGS, EF-1alpha;, microsatellite
Abstract:
Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. radicis-lycopersici (FORL) is an
important soilborne pathogen of tomato and is morphologically
indistinguishable from F. oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici (FOL), the causal
agent of Fusarium wilt. The nuclear ribosomal DNA intergenic spacer
(IGS) region, translation elongation factor 1-alpha (EF-1alpha), and a
microsatellite locus, FOL185, were used for phylogenetic analyses.
Phylogenetic topologies derived from the three loci were incongruent,
suggesting that each locus has its unique evolutionary history. Neither
EF-1alpha nor FOL185 provided useful phylogenetic resolution. In
contrast, IGS variation resolved known vegetative compatibility groups
(VCGs) of FORL and FOL, suggesting that the IGS region may be useful for
differentiating the predominant VCGs of FORL from FOL. Mating-type (MAT)
analysis showed that each VCG carried a single MAT idiomorph. Estimates
of the mean most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of FORL derived from IGS,
EF-1alpha, and FOL185 data ranged from 1969 to 1878, suggesting that
FORL is a relatively new pathogen compared to the invention of
agriculture approximately 10000 years ago. The population expansion of
FORL has been increased globally since the early 1990s. Although
physiological races of FORL have not been reported, regularly monitoring
the population structure of FORL is vital for disease management.
